results.title: I can jump puddles. Ep. 3
results.creator_credit: Kevin Dobson, John Gauci and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A 9 part television serial about Australian author Alan Marshall, from his childhood and his diagnosis with Polio to his adulthood as he struggles to become a writer. Based on his three autobiographical novels “I can Jump Puddles”, ‘This is the Grass” and “How Beautiful are thy Feet”. Alan is determined to ride his pony Katie again, however his father forbids it, as he says there is too great a chance of Alan getting hurt or killed, as his legs are no longer strong enough to grip the horse and he has trouble maintaining his balance. At school, Alan overhears a classmate complaining about exercising his pony at lunchtime, and quickly volunteers to do it, despite his father’s warnings. Although his riding is belittled by his school teacher, who tells him to focus on learning, as he is destined for a desk job, Alan continues, and eventually shows his father what he can do.

results.title: I can jump puddles. Ep. 4
results.creator_credit: Kevin Dobson, John Gauci and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A 9 part television serial about Australian author Alan Marshall, from his childhood and his diagnosis with Polio to his adulthood as he struggles to become a writer. Based on his three autobiographical novels “I can Jump Puddles”, ‘This is the Grass” and “How Beautiful are thy Feet”. Adapting quickly to life with crutches, Alan constantly tries to keep up with the other boys and do all the things that they do. His father’s friend Mr. Radcliff learns of Alan’s ambition to become a writer, he encourages Alan to start keeping a notebook, to note down good stories and yarns, and to constantly experience new things, as all these things will help him to become a great writer. When a family friend invites him to go camping, Alan takes along his notebook and goes along to experience ‘life’.

results.title: La Collectionneuse = the Collector Girl
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Barbet Schroeder and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
Feeling vaguely abandoned as his girlfriend has gone to London, Adrian, a dilettante philosopher, goes to stay at a friend’s villa on the outskirts of St. Tropez. Daniel, an avant-garde artist, and Haydee, a sweetly amoral nymphette who sleeps with a different boy every night, are there also. As the collector of the title, she causes disarray in the two men who decide it is their duty to resist her advances - an intellectual rather than physical moral superiority. It is Adrian, frustrated and chastened, who finally fulfills the moral outline of the series, by hopefully planning a reconciliation with his girlfriend. ‘La Collectionneuse’ was the first feature Rohmer made in 35mm and colour. This is the fourth installement of Rohmer’s ‘Six Moral Tales’.

Credits: Producers, Georges de Beauregard, Barbet Schroeder ; director, Eric Rohmer ; writer, Eric Rohmer ; photography, Nestor Almendros ; music, Les Blossom Toes, Giorgio Gomeslky.
Cast: Patrick Bauchau, Haydee Politoff, Daniel Pommereulle, Seymour Hertzberg.

results.title: Caroline Cherie = Dear Caroline
results.creator_credit: Richard Pottier, Alain Poire and Paul Cadeac
results.brief_description:
Caroline de Bievres celebrates her 16th birthday on 14 July 1789. While the Parisians storm the Bastille, Caroline experiences love with Gaston de Sallanches. Sent to Paris by her parents, she discovers that Gaston is already married.

Credits: Producer, Alain Poire, Paul Cadeac ; director, Richard Pottier ; writer, Jean Anouilh ; photography, Maurice Barry ; music, Georges Auric ; art director, Jacques Krauss.
Cast: Martine Carol, Jacques Dacqmine, Pierre Cressoy, Jacques Clancy, Marie Dea, Daniele Seller, Paul Bernard, Alfred Adam, Raymond Souplex, Marthe Mercadier, Nadine Alari, Yvonne de Bray, Marie Dea, Olivier Hussenot.

results.title: J'ai Epouse Une Ombre = I Married a Dead Man
results.brief_description:
Helene is 8 months pregnant when she is abandoned by Frank, her companion. Lonely and desperate she boards the first train heading south. Aboard, she meets vineyard heir Bertrand Meyrand and his wife Patricia, also 8 months pregnant. During the night, the train is derailed. Bertrand and Patricia die during the accident. When Helene wakes up at the hospital, she realises that everyone mistakes her for Patricia, including Bertrand’s parents who offer her shelter at their wine growing property. Helene settles uncomfortably in her new family, until the day Frank comes back to blackmail her. The plot is based on a story by Cornell Woolrich and was filmed twice before as ‘No Man of Her Own’ in 1932 and 1949 in the U.S.A. In 1996 it was remade again as the romantic comedy ‘Mrs. Winterbourne’.

Credits: Producer, Alain Sarde ; director, Robin Davis ; writers, Robin Davis, Patrick Laurent ; photography, Bernard Zitzerman ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Nathalie Baye, Francis Huster, Richard Bohringer, Madeleine Robinson, Guy Trejean, Victoria Abril, Veronique Genest.

results.title: Les Maries de L'an II
results.brief_description:
A few year before the French Revolution, Nicolas kills one of his wife’s lover and must flee to America in order to avoid police prosecution. While in exile he becomes a successful spice merchant. Soon Nicolas is engaged to be married to a wealthy heiress. However, he must return to France, by now in the throes of the revolution, to obtain divorce from his wife and

Credits: Producer, Alain Poire ; director, Jean-Paul Rappeneau ; writers, Daniel Boulanger, Maurice Clavel, Claude Sautet, Jean-Paul Rappeneau ; photography, Claude Renoir ; music, Michel Legrand ; art direction, Willy Holt, Alexandre Trauner.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Marlene Jobert, Michel Auclair, Laura Antonelli, Sami Frey, Denise Peron, Julien Guiomar, Charles Denner, Pierre Brasseur, Mario David.

results.title: Dangerous ground
results.creator_credit: Darrell Roodt, Gillian Gorfil, Ice Cube and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: After being in exile and living in America for the last 14 years, Vusi Madlazi (Ice Cube) returns to South Africa for his father’s funeral and discovers that South Africa has fallen into the hands of drug baron’s and gang violence. Following his father’s funeral, Vusi’s mother informs him that his brother Steven is missing, feared to be in trouble with one of the major drug baron’s‘s, Muki (Ving Rhames). Along with his girlfriend, Karin (Elizabeth Hurley), Vusi sets out to find his brother in Johannesburg. Together, they discover Stephen has become addicted to crack, owes Muki $45,000 and the debt needs to be paid or else Vusi will end up burying his brother as well.

results.title: Wildside. Eps. 1-2
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, Steve Knapman and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Bill McCoy (Tony Martin) has come back to Sydney after a four year absence, working throughout South East Asia after retiring from the police force due to the level of police corruption and his inability to turn a blind eye. His return is triggered by a phone call from his friend and crisis worker, Syd, that his son Nick is in some kind of trouble. McCoy pays a visit to his ex-wife after having no luck locating Nick, only to be told Nick ended up in a youth detention centre, unbeknownst to Bill - his wife has no idea where their son is. In his venture to locate Nick, Bill meets Dr Maxine Summers (Rachel Blake), who runs a drop in centre for delinquent youth and is treating a young boy named Joe. Joe is a suspect in a ram-raid and car chase that ended with the death of two police officers, while at the same time the body of young boy turns up; tied, raped, tortured and his throat slit.

results.title: Une Femme Douce = a Gentle Creature
results.brief_description:
A young woman marries a pawnbroker but finds she cannot adapt her life to his. She toys with murdering him, but kills herself instead. With the introduction of colour in his films, beginning with ‘Une femme douce’, Bresson’s vision darkened, his growing pessimism disclosed in an increasingly voluptuous rendering of the world. (One might say sobriety invites intoxication.) The flatness of Bresson’s compositions and his emphasis on dedramatization places Bresson in the tradition of modernism, yet his universe often seems archaic.” Reference: James Quandt. The poetry of precision: the films of Robert Bresson. Cinematheque Ontario. Online. http://www.bell.ca/filmfest/cinematheque/bresson.htm. Further reading: Film Comment. ‘Special Bresson’. May-June and July 1999

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Robert Bresson ; writer, Robert Bresson ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet ; music, W. A. Mozart, Henry Purcell, Jean Wiener ; art direction, Pierre Charbonnier.
Cast: Dominique Sanda, Guy Frangin, Jane Lobre, Claude Ollier, Dorothee Blank.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Robert Bresson ; writer, Robert Bresson ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet ; music, W. A. Mozart, Henry Purcell, Jean Wiener ; art direction, Pierre Charbonnier.
Cast: Dominique Sanda, Guy Frangin, Jane Lobre, Claude Ollier, Dorothee Blank.
